utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
You asked me one question.
It was the first one.
You are free to jump in anytime.
You've got to be, you know, these are tough guys out here.
Oh, I know, Brewster.
So let me draw in another set of players to this conversation.
Brewster referred to the Internet archives practice of collecting the publicly accessible Web and providing access to it.
I think that's a terrific service and a great project.
However, the publicly accessible citation is of great interest, because the publicly accessible part of the Web is really only something like 10 percent of everything that's available.
We have to deal with and recognize the rights and interests of the creators and the publishers who put out information, having massaged it and marketed and generated it in some cases.

And despite the fact that the current way that the copyright laws in America are written, that this material is going to be locked up for a very long time, something that I agree entirely with both Michael Hart and Brewster Kahle about, we have to find a way to bring in these other players.
And the Google Book Search project is precisely trying to do that in order to provide deep access to works in which there are still copyright interests active.
It's good to be able to see 10 percent.
It's good to be able to see the public domain works.

It's wildly important to be able to index and understand what's in works that are available for some fee or another, or available through a library in order to advance knowledge and advance study and teaching, and to serve small schools and small libraries and individuals in distant places that are distant from libraries.
Oh, Michael Hart, you got the last word.
Okay.
I'm going to sneak in here for 30 seconds.
Yes.
Go ahead.
In terms of the numbers of copies and keeping everything backed up, if you'd do a search for Project Gutenberg in Hamlet, you'll find over 10,000 copies of Hamlet out there.
That's the best backup you can have.
No matter how many gateways are down, you're still going to find it.
Now, in terms of this whole thing about copyright being locked away forever, I'm afraid Michael Keller was all too right about that.
Every time a copyright is going to expire, especially for the Mouse, copyright becomes extended all of a sudden.
So they tell us, if you leave this alone for 26 years, 28 years, 14 years, whatever the period was at the time, we'll let you have it after that period.
But that period never comes.
And I'd see we're out of time.
But Michael Keller was saying that there has to be - you have to find a way of dealing with this, and he thinks the Google people are doing it.
How do you react to that, Michael?
I'm not sure that there is a way to deal with a wolf that's got a hold of your foot.
The copyright gets longer and longer.
And unless something seriously changes, the trend of the last 300 years - you started with a 14-year copyright, is going to end up with a permanent copyright.
Nothing will - I'm not quite sure that any copyright will ever expire in the United States ever again.
Michael Keller?
I think there is that prospect.
But at the same time, I know that the publishers and the Congress would like to do the right thing.
And I would love to see us harmonize our copyright laws with our present patent laws.
I think that the copyright industry would continue to make its money, and I think there are some possibilities.
But at the same time, I think we have to expect that as a social good, all those who create content should allow that content to be thoroughly indexed.
And the active indexing of that content should not be a criminal act.

Making information accessible - that's not making the pages necessarily accessible for free, but making the information about those pages and from those pages free, freely accessible, is an important public good.
All right.
We've run out of time.
I'd like to get back to this.
This is a very interesting and developing issue.
And we run out of time.

I like to thank all of my guests, Brewster Kahle, digital librarian and director and co-founder of the Internet Archive; Michael Hart, founder of Project Gutenberg; and Michael Keller, university librarian, director of academic information resources at Stanford University in Stanford.
Thank you gentleman for taking time to be with us today.
Thank you very much, Ira.
Thank you.
(Soundbite of music)
I'm Ira Flatow in New York.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Rebecca Roberts in Washington, D.C.
Neal Conan is away.
Screening for breast cancer is a challenge - often scary, painful and confusing - and it only got more confusing over the last two weeks.
A major medical group questioned the current recommendation for regular mammograms for all women in their forties.
The American Cancer Society said women with a high risk of developing breast cancer should not only get mammograms but also MRI scans.
Yet another study said that computer-assisted mammography may provide misleading results and is no better than regular mammography.
Later in the program, our Wednesday visit with political junkie Ken Rudin.
If you have questions about national politics, you can send them to us by e-mail now.
Talk@npr.org is the address.
But first, new research on screening breast cancer.
What does this mean for women?
If mammography isn't always the best course, what is?
Join the conversation.
Our number here in Washington is 800-989-8255, that's 800-989-TALK.
Our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
And you can also join the conversation on our blog.
It's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
We begin here in Studio 3A with NPR health policy correspondent Joanne Silberner.
Welcome.
Thank you.
So Joanne, a woman could be forgiven for feeling a little whip-sawed by all of these studies this week.
What do you make of them?
Well, you know, it's true of anything in medicine, that studies will go back and back and forth until they, you know, a consensus is hit and they start to become consistent.
It's true especially with breast cancer because, well, first of all, it's a cancer, so there's a lot that people that put into that.

There's a high amount of interest in this particular cancer, which means there's a high amount of money, which means that there's a lot of research and sometimes it's going to disagree, and things keep changing.
You know, as the research goes on, as new techniques develop - you know, for example you mentioned the computer-detected cancer - or I'm sorry, the computer-detected mammography.
Well, they used the computer-detection methods that were around when they started collecting data a few years ago.
There's new computer systems around now.
You might get a different result if you did the study again, but you'd have to do the study again.
I'm interested in one thing you said earlier about how slight the exposure to subprime mortgages was for TIAA-CREF, very small, given that you're a $400 billion system.
Why?
What was it about those kind of securities that told somebody in your system ""no"" when they seemed extremely attractive to lots and lots of financial institutions?
That's a great question, and the good news was a good combination of interaction between our risk management and our asset management professionals.
And the bottom line was that they looked at those securities and said, for the underlying risk, we don't think the return is sufficiently high.
And they made what was a very, very good, smart calculation.
We were also helped by the fact that we are a privately held, not-for-profit company which means that we didn't have to chase incremental return to keep the quarter-to-quarter earning stream flowing.
Presumably, people all over the financial sector here and abroad could have done the same thing?
Presumably, they could have.
But I think they had a range of incentives, which were perfectly legal and legitimate incentives, to meet quarter-to-quarter demands.
And frankly, in many cases I think some of them are also underwriting some of those securities and marketing the securities, so there are a range of views.
We were very fortunate.
We are only an investor, and we're only a long-term investor, and we are a relatively prudent investor.
You said you're getting a lot of calls.
Your call rate is way up.
What does that mean?
What are people calling up about?
We have seen increases of 50 percent, 100 percent on some days.
On a recent weekend, we had calls to 15,000 people.
Primarily what people are doing is what I would describe as a gut check.
They want to look at their portfolio with independent objective advice that we give and ask, well, is that the right portfolio for these very troubled times?
Is the volume of calls at least going down a little bit?
The volume of calls has come off a little bit.
The only thing I worry about, frankly, is when the market drops, our call volumes spike.
And that tells me that people are staying glued to the screens worrying about the ups and downs of a very volatile market.

And frankly, for my participants, I think they should be focused in on educating and teaching, and spending less time worried about the ups and downs of markets which are going to be beyond their control and certainly, in these troubled times, very volatile.
Mr.
Ferguson, thanks a lot for talking with us.
Thank you very much.
It really was a pleasure.
Roger Ferguson is president and CEO of TIAA-CREF.
We spoke in New York City.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm Steve Inskeep.
It's believed that more than 70 percent of Iraqi voters took part in yesterday's parliamentary elections.
Some polling stations were forced to delay closing in order to accommodate voters waiting to cast ballots.
Now one day after the votes have been cast, security remains tight and Iraq is still in a virtual lockdown.
We're going now to NPR's Jaime Tarabay who's covering the election and is in Baghdad.
And, Jaime, does it feel today as though some milestone has been passed?
Well, Steve, it's still, I guess, the quiet before the storm.
There's still a curfew and the security measures that took place during election day are still in force.
So it's hard to gauge just exactly what the sentiment is out there at the moment.
Was turnout as high in Sunni-dominated areas of the country as in the rest of the country?
We don't have good figures yet, but it seems that they just came out in all the different areas including Anbar province, which is where the insurgents are very strong.
They were in Mosul in the north, even in Tikrit, in Saddam Hussein's hometown, they turned out in force.
There were complaints in Anbar province, actually, that they ran out of ballots in some places.
And some complained that there weren't enough polling stations.
Although we do need to mention that in Ramadi, which is in Anbar province, about a dozen polling stations weren't open because of those security concerns.
Is it possible to have any sense today whether that relatively high Sunni Muslim turnout means that fewer people will be willing to support violent means in Iraq, the insurgency?
